subject: RE: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or IsCollection.isEmpty()
msgSnippet: Dear David, ... This idea stands well on its own merits, and the notation does have some obvious benefits over the Hamcrest notation.  However, I have one
messageBody:
Dear David,



>I'd love a vote on this matter. I'm imagining a tool that would
>generate code to provide special-case overloads for any final class,
>with String as the first use. Also, wrappers for all primitive types
>and boolean operators, to allow
>
>assertThat(5).greaterThan(4);



This idea stands well on its own merits, and the notation does have some
obvious benefits over the Hamcrest notation. However, I have one
burning question: why not continue to improve Hamcrest? While the
notation is not stellar, it does get the job done and seems to have all
the relevant error reporting implemented.



Thank you,



Rocco



From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
David Saff
Sent: Tuesday, May 19, 2009 10:06 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or
IsCollection.isEmpty()



On Mon, May 18, 2009 at 4:21 PM, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...
<mailto:nat.pryce%40gmail.com> > wrote:
> On 18/05/2009, David Saff <david@... <mailto:david%40saff.net> >
wrote:
>> To be clear, my proposal was a single syntax that would allow
>> hamcrest-style assertions from a boolean method on any non-final
>> class, including:
>>
>> assertThat(list).isEmpty();
>> assertThat(list).equals(list2);
>> assertThat(list).contains(item);
>> assertThat(file).exists();
>> assertThat(objectStreamField).isPrimitive();
>>
>> The _big_ blocker for this idea is that String is final, meaning that
>> there's no way to use the same syntax to get this to compile:
>>
>> assertThat("abc").contains("c");
>
> You could write a special-case overload for Strings that returned some
> kind of string-matcher-builder. It's a kludge but maybe consistency
> would be worth it.

I'd love a vote on this matter. I'm imagining a tool that would
generate code to provide special-case overloads for any final class,
with String as the first use. Also, wrappers for all primitive types
and boolean operators, to allow

assertThat(5).greaterThan(4);

Who hates this idea?

> Also, what about accessors that return types other than boolean? I'm
> sure there's a way to automagically generate composite matchers for
> them somehow.

Can you be more specific?

David Saff
